content:
Welcome Hi, I’m Jiaju ‚Äî a CS student at Northeastern University. This blog is where I share what I learn about programming, algorithms, and software engineering.
Why I Started This Blog Writing helps me think more clearly. By explaining concepts in my own words, I understand them better. Plus, it’s a great way to track my learning journey.
A Quick Math Demo The time complexity of merge sort can be expressed as:
$$T(n) = 2T\left(\frac{n}{2}\right) + O(n)$$
Which gives us $O(n \log n)$ ‚Äî much better than bubble sort’s $O(n^2)$.
How I Think About Problem Solving graph TD A[Read the Problem] --> B[Identify Constraints] B --> C{Brute Force First?} C -->|Yes| D[Write Naive Solution] D --> E[Analyze Time Complexity] E --> F{Good Enough?} F -->|No| G[Optimize with Data Structures] G --> F F -->|Yes| H[Submit & Reflect] A Simple Two Sum in Java One of the classic interview problems:
public int[] twoSum(int[] nums, int target) { Map<Integer, Integer> map = new HashMap<>(); for (int i = 0; i < nums.length; i++) { int complement = target - nums[i]; if (map.containsKey(complement)) { return new int[] { map.get(complement), i }; } map.put(nums[i], i); } return new int[] {}; } This runs in $O(n)$ time using a hash map, compared to the brute force $O(n^2)$ approach.
What’s Next I plan to write about:
Object-oriented design patterns Algorithm breakdowns (sliding window, DFS, etc.) Full-stack development with React and FastAPI Lessons learned from team projects Stay tuned!

summary: About me

content:
Welcome Hi, I’m Jiaju ‚Äî a CS student at Northeastern University. This blog is where I share what I learn about programming, algorithms, and software engineering.
Why I Started This Blog Writing helps me think more clearly. By explaining concepts in my own words, I understand them better. Plus, it’s a great way to track my learning journey.
A Quick Math Demo The time complexity of merge sort can be expressed as:
$$T(n) = 2T\left(\frac{n}{2}\right) + O(n)$$
Which gives us $O(n \log n)$ ‚Äî much better than bubble sort’s $O(n^2)$.
How I Think About Problem Solving graph TD A[Read the Problem] --> B[Identify Constraints] B --> C{Brute Force First?} C -->|Yes| D[Write Naive Solution] D --> E[Analyze Time Complexity] E --> F{Good Enough?} F -->|No| G[Optimize with Data Structures] G --> F F -->|Yes| H[Submit & Reflect] A Simple Two Sum in Java One of the classic interview problems:
public int[] twoSum(int[] nums, int target) { Map<Integer, Integer> map = new HashMap<>(); for (int i = 0; i < nums.length; i++) { int complement = target - nums[i]; if (map.containsKey(complement)) { return new int[] { map.get(complement), i }; } map.put(nums[i], i); } return new int[] {}; } This runs in $O(n)$ time using a hash map, compared to the brute force $O(n^2)$ approach.
What’s Next I plan to write about:
Object-oriented design patterns Algorithm breakdowns (sliding window, DFS, etc.) Full-stack development with React and FastAPI Lessons learned from team projects Stay tuned!
